title: Terminal Basics
description: Essential terminal commands for navigating and managing files

cards.description: Displays the full path to your current working directory
cards.whenToUse: When you need to know exactly where you are in the file system
scenarios: You opened a new terminal and want to see where you are
You need to copy the current path to share with someone
You're lost after navigating through multiple directories

cards.task: List files in the current directory
cards.description: Shows all files and folders in the current directory
cards.whenToUse: When you want to see what's in a folder
scenarios: You want to see what files are in your project folder
You're checking if a file exists before creating it
You need to find the exact name of a file

cards.task: List files with details (size, date, permissions)
cards.description: Shows all files including hidden ones, with detailed information
cards.whenToUse: When you need to see file sizes, dates, or hidden files
scenarios: You want to see hidden config files like .clasp.json
You need to check when a file was last modified
You want to see file sizes

cards.description: Moves you into a subdirectory
cards.whenToUse: When you need to navigate into a folder
scenarios: You want to enter your project folder
You need to access files in a subdirectory
You're navigating to where your code lives

cards.description: Moves you to the parent directory
cards.whenToUse: When you need to go back up in the folder structure
scenarios: You're done working in a subfolder
You went into the wrong directory
You need to access a sibling folder

cards.description: Takes you directly to your user's home folder
cards.whenToUse: When you want to quickly return to your home directory
scenarios: You want to start fresh from a known location
You need to access files in your home folder
You're deeply nested and want to get back quickly

cards.description: Creates a new empty folder
cards.whenToUse: When you need to create a new folder
scenarios: You're starting a new project
You need to organize files into folders
You're setting up a directory structure

cards.task: Create a new empty file called 'notes.txt'
cards.description: Creates a new empty file or updates the timestamp of an existing file
cards.whenToUse: When you need to create an empty file quickly
scenarios: You need to create a placeholder file
You want to create a file before editing it
You're setting up config files

cards.task: Display the contents of a file called 'readme.txt'
cards.description: Prints the entire contents of a file to the terminal
cards.whenToUse: When you want to quickly view a file's contents
scenarios: You want to read a config file
You need to check what's in a small text file
You want to see the contents of .clasp.json

cards.description: Clears all previous output from the terminal
cards.whenToUse: When your terminal is cluttered with old output
scenarios: You want a fresh, clean terminal view
You're about to run an important command and want to see the output clearly
Your screen is full of previous command results

cards.description: Creates a copy of a file with a new name
cards.whenToUse: When you need to duplicate a file
scenarios: You want to back up a file before editing it
You need to create a copy to modify
You're duplicating a template file

cards.description: Moves or renames a file
cards.whenToUse: When you need to rename a file or move it to another location
scenarios: You want to rename a file
You need to move a file to a different folder
You're reorganizing your project structure

cards.description: Permanently removes a file (no trash/recycle bin)
cards.whenToUse: When you need to delete a file you no longer need
scenarios: You want to remove a temporary file
You're cleaning up old files
You created a file by mistake

cards.description: Removes an empty directory
cards.whenToUse: When you need to delete an empty folder
scenarios: You created a folder by mistake
You're cleaning up empty directories
A folder is no longer needed

cards.task: Open the current directory in Finder (Mac) or Explorer (Windows)
cards.description: Opens the current folder in your system's file browser (Mac: open, Windows: explorer, Linux: xdg-open)
cards.whenToUse: When you want to see the current folder in a graphical file browser
scenarios: You want to drag and drop files
You prefer to browse files visually
You need to open a file with a specific application

cards.task: Open a file called 'script.js' in the nano text editor
cards.description: Opens a file in nano, a simple terminal-based text editor
cards.whenToUse: When you need to edit a file directly in the terminal
scenarios: You want to quickly edit a config file
You're creating a new script file
You need to make a small change without opening a full IDE

cards.task: In nano: Save the current file
cards.description: Writes (saves) the current file in nano (then press Enter to confirm)
cards.whenToUse: When you want to save your changes in nano
scenarios: You've finished editing and want to save
You want to save before making more risky changes
You're saving periodically to avoid losing work

cards.description: Exits nano (will prompt to save if there are unsaved changes)
cards.whenToUse: When you're done editing and want to close nano
scenarios: You've finished editing a file
You want to quit without saving (press N when prompted)
You're done and ready to run other commands

cards.task: In nano: Cut the current line
cards.description: Cuts (removes) the entire current line and stores it for pasting
cards.whenToUse: When you want to delete or move a line of text
scenarios: You want to delete a line of code
You're moving a line to a different location
You need to remove multiple lines quickly

cards.task: In nano: Paste the cut text
cards.description: Pastes (uncuts) the previously cut text at the cursor position
cards.whenToUse: When you want to paste text you previously cut
scenarios: You're moving a line to a new location
You want to duplicate a line (cut, paste, paste)
You need to restore a line you accidentally cut
